response.answer_text: It’s easy to know how well you did in school, the baseball game, or even at work. But how do you grade success in life? There’s more to life than money. In school we receive grades; in baseball we count runs; and at work we get performance reviews. But life isn’t quite that simple. We may ask ourselves: “Do I have more good days or bad days? Am I doing better today than yesterday? Do I give more than I take? Am I doing better or worse than others?” At the end of a day, we may say: “Three people smiled at me, someone thanked me for doing them a favor, and my kids told me they loved me.” Not bad. But . . . it’s really hard to put a figure on intangibles such as a smile, a thank you, and the love of our children. And because these intangibles are difficult to quantify (and frequently not in the public eye), we often discount their true worth. Instead, we turn to more recognizable ways to measure success — money and the things it can buy. And why not? Money is tangible. You can feel it. You can count it. You can flaunt it. You can use it to impress others, while impressing yourself. Money is flexible. Money spells success. (Or does it?) It’s tempting to assume that if we have a better car, a bigger house, and take more vacations, we’re leading “the good life.” But, are we leading a meaningful life? The truth is, money can’t buy everything. For example, money can’t buy peace of mind, good friends, a close-knit family, work-life balance, a worry-free day, good karma, time to relax, good health, a golden anniversary, quality time with your kids, a new beginning, natural beauty, happy memories, to name just a few. Many people are actually poor because the only thing they have is money. If You Live for Money, It’s Time to Get a Life Are you willing to sacrifice your dreams for more money? Some folks justify continuing in a miserable job situation by acknowledging that they’re well compensated. The truth is, life is short. People who live a life of purpose wake up each morning excited to pursue their dreams and make a difference. — Money can’t guarantee that. Are you willing to compromise your honor for more money? Everything has a price, but not everything should be for sale. Some folks make money by being ruthless or doing unscrupulous things. People with a clear conscience have core beliefs and values that influence their decisions, shape their day-to-day actions, and determine their short- and long-term priorities. The result is that they spend more time listening to their inner voice. — Chances are, they sleep well at night. Are you willing to forgo relationships for more money? Think about “the takers.” You know them. They measure every action by how much they will personally benefit, while “the givers” do things without expectation of personal gain. Givers receive as much satisfaction (and as many karma points) by creating win-win relationships and giving to others than if they had benefited personally. — Which are you? Are you willing to miss out on life for more money? Some people don’t take time to smell the roses. It’s hard to calculate the value of memories, such as a clean bill of health, first kiss, crossing the finish line, grandchildren, passing the driver’s test, 10-year reunion, acceptance letter, visit from the tooth fairy, cheers from the crowd, retirement, “Mama . . . Dada,” bedtime stories, potty training, a beer and a burger, and “I love you, too.” It’s important to focus on the journey as well the destination. — There’s no dress rehearsal in life. Are you willing to cash in your personal dignity for more money? Some people are consumed with seeking the approval of others. The most important person to satisfy, however, is you. It’s your life. So do your best. Be your own person. And remember, you’re not finished until you do yourself proud. As John Mason, author, said, “You were born an original. Don’t die a copy.” — It’s time to be the real you. Money . . . What’s It All Worth? I’m not saying that money isn’t important. Rather, this is a plea to acknowledge that there’s more to life than money. We must assign appropriate value to the intangible areas of our lives, such as our honor, personal relationships, peace of mind, and quality family time, to name a few examples. If we take these things for granted, and lose them as a result, we are on the road to personal bankruptcy. It’s important to keep money in perspective. Do you spend more money satisfying your desires than fulfilling your needs? Do you let money dictate your activities, affect your relationships, and consume your thoughts? Is money a constant cause of anxiety and a source of stress? If you answer yes to these questions, you may be becoming a slave to your money. When you look back on your life one day, will you gauge success by the power that you attained and the wealth that you accumulated? Or, will you measure the degree to which your life was rich in character and purpose? Will it matter that you led an honorable existence, made a difference in people’s lives, and left the world a better place for your children? Albert Einstein said it well, “Not everything that can be counted counts, and not everything that counts can be counted.” The choice is yours. There’s more to life than money.

Money is an economic token - a symbol of purchasing power. Unless you're an artist or given to appreciate the artistry behind its production, the token's likely of no great importance to you. If so, your answer is obvious. Most people appreciate money for what they think it might buy for them, and that's probably what you meant to ask. Ask yourself whether you can purchase what you value as important in life. If you can, your answer is obvious. If you cannot, ... same answer. Of course, the philosophical among us would think me remiss to omit that fundamental truism you've heard all your life: Money can't buy you happiness. The capitalists will guffaw at this nostrum as something people with no money say. Rich and poor alike can see that money or its absence won't eliminate all of your problems, but it might buy you a better class of problems and problem solvers. Maybe. Who's right?  To borrow a metaphor from Scrooge McDuck, there's two sides to every coin. So, your mileage may vary. It's certainly true that money can't buy you love; it can't buy you a longer life; possessing it doesn't make you smarter or any more worthy of what's good or noble about your species. But... While money can't buy you love, it can rent access to affectionate company in fragrant surroundings. But, can you trust your pretty companions or what their true feelings toward you might be? Though it can't buy you life, it might get you medical care, which goes a long way to preventing premature death and years of suffering before your end. Still, do you think being rich will take away your fear of suffering and death? No, not so much in my experience. Of course, it doesn't make you smarter, but it might gain you access to information and opportunities to exploit the advantage of a superior bargaining position. However, will you use that opportunity to better yourself and your surroundings or just exploit the advantage until someone better positioned exploits you? Is money important? Depends on whether you think you have enough to satisfy your needs in the given moment. Of course, you might better focus on finding other ways to see your needs met and make the question superfluous. Thanks for asking.

Money is important for one simple reason: Society agrees that it's important and that it has value. As long as there has been specialization of skills, there has been a need for barter. If a person was better than others at making arrows, it made sense to give that person meat in exchange for arrows, and for that person to make arrows instead of hunting. It also would have made sense to accumulate arrow heads to trade with other tribes in times of need, etc. Thus it would have made a good currency, as long as there was no other specialization.  With more specialization, there was the need for open markets, and it was a matter of determining how much of one commodity was worth trading for another. Some would have been common enough that they were good for barter in general. Everybody could use a chicken but not everybody could use an extra spoon. So saving up spoons wouldn't have been a great idea, but when trading things that were less widely needed, it would have made sense to trade them for things that were widely needed and trade those for things that were more specific.  As time went on, precious metals met that need. Gold and silver were of limited supply, and thus could have a relatively fixed value. The laws of supply and demand could then dictate whether one person was willing to give more corn than the next farmer for the same amount of silver. Gold and silver were things anybody could use since they were universally accepted for trade. Thus they were a de facto currency.  Paper money is a more recent invention. Through most of the 20th century, the same "money" that we use today in the US, meaning bills of the same size with portraits of the same people, were issued by the Federal Reserve (among others), which agreed to "pay to the bearer on demand," a sum of gold or silver.  In the later part of the 20th century, we were told that the paper WAS the money. Had people not been used to the idea of trading these pieces of paper for goods, it would have been hard to convince anybody to give somebody a house for a stack of papers with specific pictures and words on them. But unless society was willing to stand up and point out that the Emperor has no clothes, we continue to accept it. Since those days, we had another shift where we accepted numbers printed on a piece of paper. Employers would give "pay stubs" saying that there was a direct deposit, and banks would send statements reflecting an equivalent change in balance. People would show somebody a plastic card, the paper they got in the mail would show the numbers representing the purchase, numbers would change on checking account statements and credit card statements, and we all accepted that there was "money" somewhere, which itself was more paper. These days, those printed numbers often come down to ones we see on computer screens. I can put a bunch of numbers in this post and they mean nothing, but if your bank does it, it means you have "money." If you buy something on line, you don't really need the piece of plastic, as long as you know the numbers that are on it. You trade those numbers for other things. With real property, you have tangible assets. With stock, you own portions of companies, and the paper represents a statement of ownership. But with "money," we take it on faith that others will accept the notion that government printed paper exists somewhere, and numbers we see on our computer screens represent it. If we decide that it's nothing but numbers, and the paper is something that might help make a moderate fire, then the whole thing falls apart. But if we accept it, we have something of tangible value that is universally accepted, and the laws of supply and demand let us determine what things are worth relative to each other. Money gives us the means to make those exchanges, and that includes the ability to exchange effort for goods.

I’m not rich but I want to be. At what cost? I do not know. I’ll not do anything unethical to do it. I believe I will stay that way forever I believe but money is a funny thing. Don’t judge me for saying this but Money is the most important thing in life. Let’s face it. We all work for money. People say that character is important, peace is important and so many other things. Let me list a few ironies God is supposed to be loving. While there is a long queue to worship him in religious places, there is also a paid queue which is considerable shorter and gives people quick access. If even God is swayed by money, what are mortals.A politician was convicted of a scam. He/She was found guilty in court and sentenced. He/She waited in jail for a few weeks, paid and got bail. He/She owns news channels, intimidates people with money, buys people with money and the society sings praise of the said person. Surprisingly, this applies to several politicians in the world.Who is the most successful man in the world? How many of you think of people who are not rich? I rest my case.Even an actor who tells you that money is not everything in an advertisement gets money for doing that commercialI once remember writing a short story where I call money as the “one single truth” and “singularity”. I’ve not seen God but I have seen the power of money. Money is both a master and servant to man. Money is what drives man. Maybe it is the only omnipresent thing. I saw this quote by Krishna Kumar Joshi below and it was apt “Money is not everything in life, but make sure that you have enough before you think of such nonsense.” Without money, nobody even takes you seriously. Money is a drug. You never have enough of it. Very few people do. Money is the thing that makes you break every barrier. How is progress measured in work? Appraisal. What is appraisal? Designation, power and in the end … More money This was an epic scene and the brutal truth  We have the example of several noble people who lived great lives but poor ones. They died penniless and stayed in the hearts of people but they did die poor. Exceptions like Gandhi, Mandela, Mother Teresa and so on may you think twice about money. They show you that other things are important but today, even to help others you need money. That is the brutal truth. The mere mortals need money and that is the truth. So, yes. Money is the thing that matters most in life

Money! The way I see it, money has three roles at both the personal and at overall society/civilisation level: Medium, Measure, Motivator. Let's look at each one of these and determine if money is a necessary construct. Medium: we need to use a common denominator to exchange things that we have a surplus of with the things that we want. We earn wages or produce goods ourselves and we need to exchange these into food, heat, energy, clothes, house etc. That's where money comes in. Without a common denominator, the economy will not function in an efficient manner, like it was during barter system days.Now the question is, how much does one need to buy stuff, or in other words, does having more money to exchange with the goods that one can buy translates directly into more satisfaction or happiness. There was a study I read some time ago by either Harvard or another similar institution that money does buy happiness, but only to a certain amount. I think the figure was around USD 75,000 per year for an average family in the US, where the amount of money was directly proportional to happiness in life, but it flatlined post that.I think this means that money is important as a medium of exchange till one achieves the basic standard of life and can afford the necessities, but beyond that it is not important. Of course, there are people who would want to live a much more lavish lifestyle than 75k can buy, but that is more to do with personal coding and is a complex issue in itself.Measure: the second function money has is a measure. It is often a measure of value in the current human society which primarily is economics driven. I know my last statement is open to discussion, that our society is economics driven, but I believe there is a fair amount of truth in that. Money being the common denominator serves this purpose very well. Whether it is the relative success of a company, a country, a society or a person, it can be measured via the economic contribution. Again people will say how is the economic contribution a good measure or the only measure. I agree that it is not the only measure of a cause or action in the society, however, money does serve as a measure at a vast majority of places and even the most obscure things like political ideologies or liberal views can be translated into economic or monetary measure. The abolition of racial tensions directly leads to better earnings and lifestyle for the minorities and money helps us measure that.Motivator: money can be a great motivator. It follows from its role as a medium or measure. I worked in my life initially to earn so that I could pay for a comfortable life. Then I worked so that I could earn more than my peers- simply because money was a measure of how well I was performing compared to them. Now I work towards an idea that will hopefully turn into a society changing endeavour and the commercial success is a great motivator. Again, I do not say that money can be the only motivator, but it is a great motivator as a measure of my capability to bring changes that I want to.Hence, if you ask me, I would say that money is a useful construct for the society. Is it a necessary construct? That is debatable. It is necessary for current society, for sure. Will we have a society one day where money is not a necessary construct? I think so. If we have gotten to a stage where scientific and technological innovations have brought such abundance of food, shelter and other necessities that there is no competition for them, then all we will work for is pure knowledge or pleasure or social standing. Then money may have lost its purpose. Ideas and value added by a person could be measured in a different way. Even further, we could get to a stage where we as a species would have transcended the material needs and only concern ourselves with the spiritual needs and peace within our own consciousness, and in that state money will be utterly useless. But not today. Today we do need it for society to function. Money!

Dear Friend, How much money does one require to simply live? And how much is the money people are chasing? Are they chasing it for just the basic needs of physical survival? For the insecure mind, work and money are cheap substitutes for the real essence of life. When there is absence of self-awareness, then getting respect from others becomes important. Money hides our inner hollowness. Money is a substitute for love and freedom. When life is loveless, then accumulating money becomes important.  And that is why people work. Not for bread. Simple bread is so simple to earn. To maintain the false self, money and designation and brand are desperately needed. So, people tolerate all kinds of nonsensical works, of which there are plenty. Keynes, the great economist, had said in the first half of the last century that soon the population of the world will need to work only very little, because of improved productivity of machines. Instead we find that we are being pushed to work more and more. A survey says that most jobs in economy today are not productive at all and they actually need not exist. Man goes on slogging and missing the relaxed joy of life. Not for his needs but for his pitiable greed. And to maintain his job and his greed and his foolish sense of security, he will tolerate all nonsense for six days a week. And then, he will party on the seventh day to forget his hell. Soon enough, comes another Monday. Your basic needs are quite small. You will get the money for that, don’t worry. Existence is not that cruel. Existence is not so cruel that you will starve without money. Your fundamental needs are just food, clothing, shelter and you will get enough money for that. There is no great problem in that. You do not require money for your fundamental needs.  Do you know why people need money? People need money because they are hollow within, and they think that money can fill that hollow. Money cannot fill that hollow.  The amount of money that is needed to just live comfortably is not much. You will get that. Don’t worry :) A lot of content for this answer is coming from my blog “Words into Silence”. You may refer to the blog for a deeper clarity and understanding of life. SB

There are several things that are important in life, and money is one way of gettimg some of those. As humans, in order to survive we need food, shelter, security, clothing... add some more XXI century items, education, access to internet, social contact, to develop all your potential. So, for basic survival, you either need money or the equivalent resources to get what money offers: land and strength to grow your own food, hunt or fish what you need from the land. If you want to go further and learn, interact and live a connected XXI century life, I think it becomes harder to make that happen without money. Now, that doesn't mean money is an end on itself, it is a way of getting things to enable your self fulfillment.  Picture this: you live in an empty building and you are living OK in the first floor.  Then you think that by getting to the second floor you may have a nicer view, and you try to climb there, but there are no stairs to do so.  Think of money like a ladder that will take you to the second floor and provide you with a better view.  Once in the second floor, you either feel great and rest or you try to climb to another floor to see if it is nicer.  Then you need a second ladder.  You may become obsessed about getting more ladders, and, like some people, stay in the first floor and accumulate ladders (which obviously makes no sense).  You may also become obsessed with climbing up, so that you never enjoy the floor you live in, and which may be perfect for you. In summary, money is important as long as it helps you survive and grow.  But besides that, what is important is how you manage to be happy.

Money is a means to an end. It is one of the most straight-forward gateways to get what you want, but is often not necessary. Money simply has an end most people do not think about. What would happen if you were to consistently generate more and more income? How much would it truly take for you to purchase everything you wanted? If you had the big house with 3 swimming pools, the private jet, the luxury cars, if you could travel wherever, whenever, and bought some incredibly nice things, what would be left to spend your money on? Truly consider this. No matter how much money you make, eventually you will run out of things to do with it. That is why a lot of extremely rich people become depressed or start becoming extremely charitable, because the money does not matter at that point anymore. Sure, you can always make more, but what will you do with all of that? That being said, up until that point, money can open a lot of doors; just know that it is not everything. Rich, poor, or average income, people can be happy, successful, fulfilled, feel confident, self-doubt or sadness, they can be the nicest people in the world or the worst. Money is not a defining factor for any of it, else they would not be spread so widely. That does not mean that money holds no value at all. If you are so stressed about your finances you drive yourself to depression or apathy it’s not good either. Money can solve a lot of problems, but it does not make or break anything, just like most things don’t. So… is it important? The answer to that is Yes and No.

I'd certainly think it is, because what kind of life do you have if you only work to make more money, sure it's great that one day you'll have a nice house and cars along with nice things in your house to have, but what good are they if you are never there to use them, and you'll really start to feel like you have wasted your life when you get older and realize that you never had any experiences that everyone else did, and if it hits you when you are older you'll feel like it's too late to go do a lot of those things because it's a kid crowd, and you'll say why the hell didn't I take some time off to go do all those things, and now I'm too old to do those things, so you'll feel like you missed a whole life and now it's too late because you can't reverse time, so what do you get to experience now, and then you might really hate yourself, so if you can make money and enjoy yourself too by having a lifestyle, then great because you need money to do things, but if you only have it in a bank account so you can say I have it then what's the point in having it, because you'll miss your whole life working towards gain, for me life is all about connection's with others and experiencing all that life has to offer so when I'm too old I can settle down and be happy feeling like I enjoyed my life, just remember to keep a line between working and having fun because in order to succeed you need to have some money and some time, I hope this helps you and you think about it for a while.

Important is an interesting word. Money is not necessary to be a success. No, money is not important to be a success. Your willpower, your dreams and your willingness to do whatever it takes to accomplish your mission or goals is most important. I have seen funny things under the sun. A young man with money from his father who is afraid to take a chance as he is afraid to fail, when in fact, if he were to “fail” he’d have all the money he needs to live a very comfortable and rich life or try again. And a young woman who had nothing from nothing sell things she did not have using only her own willpower, enthusiasm and imagination shared to others who was never afraid to fail and as such did not even notice when she did. The young woman became successful and money followed. The young man is still today searching for an idea that is truly his own. Of course, if you have both money and will power things can be easier! Of course, if you observe someone from the outside with money it may look like things are easier for them. But no, money is not important for your FIRST success. In fact, I would say money before your first success can be a big hindrance. Small steps, keep moving forward, and you can achieve your dreams.

Money is the backbone of any economy. It is the means of exchange, and in any advanced society will emerge naturally from barter exchange. A standard example to explain why money is important is to look at a situation of a complicated barter exchange. Imagine that you need product Z, but you have product A. You then go to someone and ask them if they can trade you product Z for product A. They say that unfortunately they do not need A, but they do need B, so if you bring them B - they will trade you Z. Unfortunately, the person who has B does not want A, but instead wants C. Person who has C wants D. And maybe only the person who has D will finally trade it for A. You then must take D to trade it for C, take C to trade it for B, then take B and trade it for Z. Such a complicated situation would be simplified if we had some product Y, that would be accepted by anyone, either because they need it or because they know that they can always trade it. Eventually, the value of product Y will be not in its commodity use, but more in its use as means of exchange. And there you have - money. Historically, both silver and gold emerged as money, and then depending on the country, either one or the other was used as the “main money”. Why were these metals chosen? If we take a look at gold, it has several properties that make it usable as means for exchange. It is rare enoughIt is relatively easy to divide it chemicallyIt does not rust and spoil with timeThis is not a complete list, but it should give the idea. Today we are not trading in gold and most currencies are no longer backed by gold. They are called fiat currencies, or fiat money, which is money that has no intrinsic commodity value, but is instead enforced by government regulation. While a minority of economists think that this is a problem, the vast majority do not believe that a return to gold-based currency is a good idea. Further reading might include: History of money - WikipediaCommodity money - WikipediaRepresentative money - WikipediaFiat money - Wikipedia

Yes. Hard Time in my Life From 8th grade during school holiday. I used to work as helper for building home not with my father.I gave all money to my mother. One day when I was 9th class,unfortunately I went to work with my father. He fell down around 20 feet height to ground .I was also there when he was doing painting a house due to some problem in building . People helped me,We took him to hospital ,My Village doctor told me to take my father to Mangalore Hospital.We went to Hospital. X ray is done then doctor told me that both right leg and hand got fructured .Need to do operation . Someone called to my mother and explained situation but she don’t know either me or my father got fructured.She rushed to hospital. Operation done .We didn’t leave my father .No one helped to us including my father friends, any family member.My mother saved money it helped us. My mother used to taken care my father during morning to evening ,I was used to take care at night. Me and mother was there in hospital for more than one month . My elder sister started work as labourer in small shop and she used taken care my younger brother. My father started getting up better day by day .It took him 8 months to recover. Money matters a lot. During those 8 months ,we were struggling for money .My mom started going for work ,My sister and me also started to work as labourer whenever school holidays. House owner told us vocate house ,That time nobody is ready to give house for rent because my father is an Alcoholic. My mother found one house she explained situation to house owner .He agreed to give house for rent .she cried each time ,when she is carrying luggage to vocate new house because she don’t have much money to carry on vehicle .She carried all luggage herself ,we just helped small luggage which we can afford to take. My father stopped drinking liquor by himself .My mother started to hate those people who didn’t help us when we are in difficult situation. After he recovered I used to go to work with him whenever I got holidays. Learnt lesson money matters a lot .Please save it from now .

One of my friends explained to me that true poverty is more about lack of good relationships than lack of money or income. This sounds profound and it might be, but he also meant it in a very practical sense. Work RelationshipsThe most obvious "good" relationship that a person needs to have to escape poverty is a job. Small business owners, meanwhile, need a network of suppliers and customers and other contacts. Employees need good relationships with their bosses, ways to get additional training, health care services, and some co-workers to cooperate with. FriendshipsA person also needs friends and family. When they lose their job or are going through hard times, they may need to save money and live off of the generosity of their closest relationships, at least for a little bit. When a person has a job, friends and family help them remember their responsibilities so they don't lose it. CharityFor people who have lost their jobs, broken their relationships with family (possibly by calling too often for help or destructive behavior), charity organizations like the Red Cross step in and lend a hand. GovernmentLastly, many countries provide local and national services to the poor. The "Poor" Rich ManAs a counter-example, he mentioned how quickly extremely wealthy athletes and other millionaires / billionaires often lose their money after they stop getting paid. The problem wasn't money. They probably had more than enough to last a lifetime or at least get another job. The point is that focusing on money first misses the important issues. That said, there are many people with normal relationships who still need to think about money. BlessingsMoney can be a blessing. Having a lack of money can easily spark ceaseless arguments in a marriage, arguments which have no easy answer. Money gives you freedom to enjoy life and your relationships more fully, without having to panic at every purchase.  In terms of economic theory, money makes it easier to trade with people without having to worry about much more complex problems with barter (How do move and store all this stuff that I've traded for, so that I can get the stuff I really want?). Most people expect and take money as payment, while strategies for living money free are difficult to work out in practice. There are many societal and technological advances that have moved us from having almost every member of a community operating their own farm to almost none of them doing so, and money was an important part of that, as it made the distribution of food much more efficient. This is distinguishing money as currency from money as wealth, which is interesting but probably not what the question was really asking. CursesMoney can also be a curse. It always slips through your fingers much faster than you expect, so having a lot of money might be deceptive. As with all property, money needs to be managed wisely. Managing larger amounts of money seems to be much harder than small amounts, as you need to work much harder to keep it safe and productive. Even if you do not believe that properly managing property is important in a spiritual sense, no one wants to be the billionaire who loses all of their money through their own foolishness. While many people will have sympathy for the poor beggar, no one will have sympathy for the poor man who wasted his money. It is much more difficult to lower your standard of living than to learn to live with a higher income. The rich poor man can always invest his extra money and take more and more control over it as they gain experience and discipline. The poor rich man, however, suddenly has to learn a ton of new disciplines with regard to saving money, which he never had to before because of his wealth. Money is not important if you live in an isolated island. You build you own house, grow up your own food, get your own water, etc… People call it now living off the grid… Living in a society, money gives you access to other people time. The 10$ you spend on food item in a grocery store is going to the store clerk who puts the item in place, to the truck driver who transported it, to the farmer who planted it, to the water company who transported water to that farm for irrigation, etc… There was a research about money and happiness, to answer the question: “Does having more money make people happy?”. In conclusion, they found that more money correlates with more happiness when a person is making less than 75K $ per annum. But when the income increases more than that, more money does not bring more happiness…. (ref: Money can buy happiness, but only to a point) More recent research found that this might not be the case, except for the US ;) (Money Does Buy Happiness! (We Were Shocked, Too) Ultimately, happiness is an internal emotion created by your perception. Your internal dialog is what creates your emotions. I ask you to challenge that belief: Is money important in your daily life? How much is money important? Is it the most important thing in “your” daily life? Are there more important things for you than money? I personally believe some money are essential, but not sufficient for my daily life. Other things are required. I believe money is a tool, utility that can be used wisely or in an unwise way.

Money is only a tool. It will take you wherever you wish, but it will not replace you as the driver. –Ayn Rand 2. Happiness is not in the mere possession of money; it lies in the joy of achievement, in the thrill of creative effort. –Franklin D. Roosevelt 3. Empty pockets never held anyone back. Only empty heads and empty hearts can do that. –Norman Vincent Peale 4. If money is your hope for independence you will never have it. The only real security that a man will have in this world is a reserve of knowledge, experience, and ability. –Henry Ford 5. Yes but not in isolation. Look at it this way: Would you be happier with $1M but dead in 1 year?Would you be happier with millions but with poor health?Would you happier with loads of money but all your family to die or stop seeing youOf course not. Moreover, spending money on pointless material things doesn’t make most people happy beyond a certain level. Now sure, it is true, if you are poor living in a poor country, the extra income makes a huge difference. If you can only afford to eat rice, and suddenly you can afford to eat a more varied diet, that will probably improve your happiness , health and mood as a well-balanced diet is connected to mood. But in the developed world, beyond $50,000-$60,000 a year, money doesn’t change your quality of life too much. If you earn more, you just go to different places. Somebody on 60K can still go on holiday, can still go to the bar. They just won't be able to regularly buy luxury goods. However, what money can buy, beyond materialism, is: Time Time for their businessTime with family2. Choice  The choice to carry on working or stopThe choice to work part-time or study full-time again as you don't need the income.3. Linked to point 2, the choice to not over consume and instead use income for wealth and financial freedom  People who don't use money in this way, even high-income people, often need to work in their 70s.4. The opportunity to try and fail  Some people, especially those with no wealth who have families and mortgages, can't take many risks.5. Travel and live overseas  Money and wealth gives you the option of passive income, and the ability to open your mind.So yes, money is important, although it shouldn't come before your health and wellbeing. Curiously, some things are good for both your health and your wealth, like giving up smoking, drugs and alcohol. Do you want to be financially free online?

Of course, money is important but only to certain extent. What do I mean by this? Take a homeless guy in the street for example. Common perception is to judge completely of having such critique such as he’s healthy. He’s got both arms and legs - he’s able to work but he doesn’t. Or maybe he’s brought this upon himself. Or he will just use the money for alcohol, drugs. etc and of course there is an element of truth in this. There are other reasons too. But I refuse to believe this. Sure, he might have made some bad choices that may have resulted in this life. However every situation has a reason just like the consequence. Every person has a story - let’s say this old man you are used to seeing in the streets. His wife had passed away as well as his kids in a car accident 30 years ago and has been suffering since. Once a vibrant, loving and hardworking family man who married his high school sweetheart who had promised her the rest of their lives to live and raise their beautiful two children up. Or that this woman had turned to alcohol and drugs because of her son who died in action. Once a loving, sweet lady whose husband passed away due to a stroke shortly after her son. Her only son too. I can go on. I’ve met and talked to few. Veterans. Chefs. Alcoholic - one even admitted to me straight up. You name it. This is much more than just something money could fix. It’s an emptiness - something a regular folk wouldn’t be able to understand. We need to help those who are in need and not look at it as a burden of the society. Only human interaction could do this I feel but then again, we are complex. Life is complex. So many barriers to even go through to get their trust so they can open up to RIGHT people. By giving them money, it is not going to solve anything so really, what use is money? Money is nothing special. stop treating like it can actually help people. Like my parents say ‘it comes and go’ - your family. The people who you consider the most important, the memories you make. Your happiness and how you want to spend your life while we have it. These are some of the things we take for granted everyday. Everyday is a blessing in disguise but unfortunately, certain situations are inevitable. It is bound to happen therefore we must find ways to help such people in need that are living recklessly, dying unnecessarily. Mental health is only recently been talked about with such openness but we really need to get the message there and actually do something about it. We must find more ways to help. This is where I am focusing with my life. Us humans can do extraordinary things but only if we have a strong mental health. Correct mindset. And I swear to god, this is the only difference between us mere mortals to those who have been ahead in life than someone who hasn’t. We need to understand that money cannot fix us. It cannot complete us. See, I view it as life itself being much bigger than money and having the sense of duty to live life well and serve others. Help others. To actually help people, we must do everything we can so they can get back on track of living a life. A strong mental health or…it could be anything. After all, what are we all really without money? or even with money itself? nothing- just the difference of situations maybe which is the truth. Where in life, such uncertainty could happen to anyone. Where we know so much about ourselves, the universe but then again we really don’t know anything. What are we really doing here? no one knows what the hell we are doing. No idea how a human being can obtain if that’s the right word that get cruel diseases. Are we chosen? still haven’t found such treatment for cancer. It is all a mystery. I could go on. In grand scheme of things, we are clueless if you actually think about it. So next time you see someone in the street, instead of being afraid and trying to avoid them. Strike up a conversation with them. You are bound to learn something, trust me. That’s what this man did to me and he showed me more decency than anyone I’ve ever met. If anything, he said he felt happy everyday but I knew he needed some help. What’s more? He didn’t ask a dime off me. We just shared a great moment - Thanks Phil. You’re a top geezer like you said in your own words. So we ask ourselves, is money even really important? We made money. Created money. Before money, humans still existed. We can live without money. In this sense, money is nothing. It’s important but not the important. *God forbid those things I’ve used as an example to anyone above.

so many ways to answer this. I don’t think money is “More important” than everything, but it sure helps everything but in the end, what really matters? Consider this… if you were told you had days to live, or perhaps were on your deathbed, what would you wish you could have had, done,been, etc.? Is money on the top of your list? For most, the answer may be time - many wish they had more time, or had done the things they’ve always wanted to do, … Money isn’t the most important, but if you had more of it, you could likely do more of the things that ARE important: Spend more time with loved ones, friends, family, etc. How many people could work less if they had more money, thereby giving more of their time and attention to children or aging parents. Given more to charities and things that were close to the heart Provided more opportunities to children, dug water wells in Africa, helped homeless people in your hometown. Sure, we can do these things now without a lot of money, … but imagine what you could do with abundant resources. Luke 12:48 says this “From everyone who has been given much, much will be demanded; and from the one who has been entrusted with much, much more will be asked.” Personally, I walked away from a 6 figure income to have more time with my aging mother and young daughter and it was worth EVERY penny lost. (got 5 more years of my mothers life, being there for her daily) More money would have helped tremendously, but money was NOT the driving factor for the decision to walk away from my job and figure out how to make it on less. I will never regret making that decision :) Hope that makes sense. Blessings,

Money is not everything but it’s the only thing that people count. Forget how many followers you got here. Forget likes. What are you going to do with these? Can you count these to put bread on your table? No. Money may not be everything but it’s like breathing. If it stops flowing to you, you can count on this very fact that you’re going to be in deep trouble. You become so limited when it comes to paying your bills, stuck in situations like location where you live, not being able to pay your debt off, your student loans, limited on food you can buy, the style of clothes, the experiences to travel, the days where you can help a member of your family get a piece of cake in life; and most of all, putting food on table for you and your family. It is very important because it allows you a lot more freedom with resources, you can leverage to do things, it can help you achieve your dreams buy hiring the best team, best tools, best resources, open contacts and door ways for you to speed up the process of success. If your income is lower than your outgoing, you’ll always be poor, working your ass off but if you learn to make your income higher than your outgoing and it grows without you with different assets, residual income, you’re not going to worry about money. Poor is not something to talk positive about or glamourise. If you’ve been poor you’d know how stuipid it is when someone says to you, “money is not important.” You know how stuck it made you feel and become when you didn’t have any. You’ve seen how people judged you with where you live, with your poor teeth you have no money to fix, where you couldn’t afford health insurance, the clothes you wear, how you are poor. People judge you. People do not respect you. People assume a lot of things about you because of how money plays an important role in the social world and social heirachy, and they can see and know you’re not even on first step of that ladder. Money can be a powerful tool to leverage, to change your life, to gain a lot more respect from society and yes, it can also attract people you want, business deals, other deals and even people you’re attracted to because you show you got the ability of knowing how this world really works. Money may not be everything but it’s like breathing. Moment it stops flowing to you, is can count on hard times is coming. Don’t mix money with “values” like belief. Money counts in this world, whether we like it or not.

These days, it’s hard to generally survive daily without having spent / spending money on things. I live with my parents and they pay for central heating, water, rent of the house, food, WiFi and nearly everything else in the house. It cost them something once (and still do for most things) to get all that. None of it was/is free. Nobody gifted/gifts them any of it.  Money is important to get most physically needed necessities like food, (water where I live and heating if you live in a cold place like me), types of temporary (but not largely temporary) and/or permanent shelter etc. Money can’t buy things like love, types of health (incurable defects from birth for an example), feelings, souls, thoughts*, beliefs*, opinions* etc. Most of our lives depend a lot on money to get going and of course survive. For that reason, money can be considered pretty important in our general lives. *These asterisked things are things you could possibly buy in rare situations. These situations usually don’t have a huge significant effect on life in general per say, like getting shelter or buying food to survive would. For an example : you can pay someone to give their thoughts, opinions and edits to an essay you wrote for something (basically proofread for you). That’s literally paying for an opinion and thoughts.

I cannot possibly explain the importance of money without showing you my thought process… Firstly, how you attain the money is important. To borrow a cliche - The journey is more important than the destination. How I Got the Money Firstly, I will think about how I managed to get this large sum of money - is it an accumulation throughout the years or is it a one-time surprise? Is it easy for me to earn my next million, or the chances are as slim as the next smartphone? The reasoning behind this increment in my finances will play a huge part in how important it is. Yes, the value of my efforts will affect the value of the money.Secondly, what can money do? Re-Investment Perhaps one good way to manage the sum of money, is to re-invest in what it had brought you that fortune? For instance, the business, investments, yes. Gambling, lottery, no. After such allocation, then I will take a fraction of the remaining sum to give back to my supporters. I will give a portion to my family and friends in 2 ways - one as a form of treat, the other as cold, hard cash. The question is, how much? This brings us to the third step.Context How old am I? Do I have my own family, kids? What are things between my family and friends different from now? Does anyone I know have any debts? Do I have to pay off any liabilities? After keying in this factor, then perhaps I will be settling the financial obligations first or stashed a larger amount to giving back to my family.Finally, after I have considered the above, the remaining will be what I can afford to spend on myself. Since you can already tell that I think too much sometimes, you probably would have anticipated the rest of the answers to be in lists as well. And you’re right. Planning for my future self This depends again, at the age of which I got the sum of money. For instance, perhaps now I would want to take an MBA, but have put it aside because of financial woes. Perhaps when I’m 50, I want to plant a herb garden, or go overseas for volunteer work. Things like these that require financial assistance requires some planning as well.Doing things for my past self Things that I wanted to do when I was young, but never got the chance to. I guess you can say now that I am chasing my childhood dreams, such as going for music lessons. And I want to change my wardrobe. I don’t mean the clothes inside, but the actual cupboard, which was passed down to me from others. I never found the need to change it, and because of that I feel that my room is a little incomplete.Present self Materials I can buy to feel good. I don’t usually buy a lot of things, but I want to get a new pair of sneakers. And perhaps a car, for my ease of transport. Maybe more ice cream. A gym membership? The list never ends though sometimes, materials are overrated. Plus, they come with other ‘side-effects’ that you have to deal with, such as buying a $5000 pair of shoes will make you more worried in dirtying it.All in all, I try to reduce decision making in my life, especially high involvement ones. More importantly, I don’t think I have a lot of time to either i) shop for the things I want or ii) spend time using the things I bought. So is money important? Yes because it is a powerful tool that we can use to buy time and to make other people happy. Is it the most important? Like an equation that has many variables, for example, A + B + C + D = E + F + G + H I don’t think any of the variables ABCD are more important than any other. By extension, it is not the most important. It depends on your dependence on it, and if you cannot rid yourself of this reliance, then perhaps you need to attain a minimum amount of wealth before other things get more important. (like the limiting factor in an equation, you know) Just be careful not to get too absorbed into it. :)

From Austin Middleton's answer to How does a monetary system work, in layman's terms? What is money's purpose in exchange? Money helps solve the mutual coincidence of wants problem.  Consider a world with three people: Alan, Brian, and Carl. Alan grows asparagus, Brian broccoli, Carl carrots. They each only produce one crop, but they would prefer to eat a variety of foods.  The thing is, they like things in different degrees. Alan likes Brian's broccoli, Brian likes Carl's carrots, and Carl likes Alan's asparagus. There's no pairwise trade to be made.  Alan wants to give Brian some asparagus in exchange for his broccoli, but Brian doesn't want asparagus: he wants carrots.Similarly, Brian wants to give Carl some broccoli in exchange for carrots, but Carl doesn't want broccoli, he wants asparagus.Same for Carl and Alan.Furthermore, even if they were all able to get together and do a three-way-swap, they'd have to all have the precise amounts of their own good relative to the others to enable that swap. Maybe Alan only has two bundles of asparagus when Carl would only accept three bundles to convince him to give his carrots to Brian. Add to that the fact that all three crops would have to ripen at the same time to ensure you get what you "paid" for, and you've made a clearly beneficial trade between the three much less likely to happen. Money solves this problem by enabling pairwise trades to happen more frequently, more easily, in the gradients that people want. Instead of Brian having to find Alan to acquire asparagus to trade for carrots with Carl, he simply offers Carl money in exchange for his carrots. Why would Carl accept this money? Because he believes that Alan will accept that self-same money in exchange for asparagus next week when it finally ripens.  So money enables exchanges of goods and services between multiple people that would be much more difficult, if not impossible, without it. If that's money, then what is a money system? Once you have a money, a good which best enables complicated transactions of goods and services between people, you produce prices. Asparagus for $2, broccoli for $4, etc. The essential characteristic of prices is their relative price: broccoli sells for twice as much as asparagus. Or, when you purchase one stalk of broccoli, you necessarily forsake the purchase of two bundles of asparagus. These relative prices can give you an idea about what people value; and if you know what other people value, then you are better equipped to tailor your own production decisions to ensure that others will exchange their money for your product. Why care about that? Because if you make something other people want, then you'll be able to convert your single product into that variety of things you desire. Just like how Alan's asparagus farm allows him to eat not simply asparagus, but broccoli and carrots as well.  Relative prices change because preferences over consumption goods changes. 10 years ago I had no idea what I was missing because I didn't eat avocados; now I love the little green taste-pods. When I purchase avocados I signal to the grocer that avocados are valuable; they then desire to stock more, so they make a larger order at the avocado farm; the farm receives more orders, so they enlarge the acreage they devote to growing avocados. If, heaven forbid, I develop an avocado allergy and stop buying them from my grocer, the reverse happens.  If the price system is sufficiently-smoothly functioning, then production will tailor itself to meet the consumptive preferences of those engaged in exchange.

This is a very personal question. Some people regard money as a scoring system, always seeking to earn more and build more wealth. They measure their success by how much money the have control over. So money is a primary motivation for them. To them it’s very important. Other people have different goals, like experience goals. For example, learning to fly, flying your own airplane on an adventure junket to Alaska, learning to sail, sailing your own boat across the Atlantic, operating a mission in a needy area of the world. For them, money is a means to an end, so it’s not important in itself, but it’s important to have enough to achieve your goals, but more than enough isn’t important. I’m more the latter. I’m an accomplishment and experience junkie. In my life I’ve treaded a somewhat peculiar path of making enough to fund my passions, but always making sure that making money didn’t consume so much of my time and attention that I wasn’t able to pursue those passions. So I guess, in answering your question, I would say “No”, money isn’t the most important thing, your passions are. Pursue your passions - they will feed your soul.

Go make some!

Importance of money in our life  Money is not everything in life but it is true that money can buy lots of things. It goes without saying that all services and products are quantified in terms of green bucks. After the barter trade went out of fashion, money has taken its place and made transactions simple for the people. In short, it has become part and parcel of our lives. How money plays an important role in our daily life? Medical facilities: People get quality medical care only when they are able to pay for the services in terms of credit card or cash. If they do not have money, they can only dream of going to the doctor and get medicinal treatment. It is required to meet the charges of the doctor and cost of medicinal manufacturing. Money can definitely buy happiness: People with money can buy homes and vehicles of their choice. They can rule the roost in the materialistic world. If they are able to fulfil the wishes, individuals would not feel jealous of others. They are happy and contended as money can fund their lavish style of living. Symbol of authority: Money generates power and authority which every woman loves. It works like an aphrodisiac that would cement the bond between the couples. Since money is in abundance, spouses do not fight with each other and live a wonderful life. They can afford to engage in the activity of their interest no matter how expensive it is. Barometer of success: No matter what people say, money is still the barometer of success. Individuals who have got a huge bank balance and live a flashy lifestyle. Skill courage, appearance, personality, power, and prestige are the parameters to judge a person and they can only be achieved with the help of money in life. Fit life: A fit and healthy life is not possible if you are a pauper. People who have to regularly worry about daily bread and butter cannot concentrate on developing a fitness regime for themselves. If you are flush with cash, it is possible to join the gym of choice and undergo training under the supervision of experienced instructors.People looking to develop their physique should have ample money to buy supplements as they are expensive. In addition, developing the personality also requires the magic bucks. Clothes that define the appearance of the person can only be purchased with money. Money defines relationships: It is sad but true fact that majority of relationships in the world is based on the flow of money not only in professional but also in personal space. As a person, you should stay clear of the buddies who are financial parasites. They can make you pauper by the time you realise what is happening. Avoid relationship with girls who are only after your money and treat you as their sugar daddy. A true friend will never allow you to waste money on unnecessary expenditure especially on his or her comfort. Learn to save hard earned wealth and invest intelligently in leading a happy and healthy life in the future.

It’s important but also not so important. Among my circle of friends and family, they always say this sentences. ‘ Money is not everything but without money you can’t do anything’ It’s important when: You want spend more time to sit down and have a nice meal with your family members.You are ill and admitted to hospital, enormous amount of money was needed for operation and hospital expenses.You have a dream that need money. For example, starting a business, travelling, buy a house and others…You want to make sure your children have the freedom to choose and do what they like to do not because they need to.You want to give your children, parents and the other half a life not just survive.It’s not important when: Your family members quarrel and fight because of allocation or distribution of the money.All you want is someone to genuinely care and love you not your money.You want to genuine friends/lover but you not sure they become friends is because of you or your money.Acquired new skill or something similar that related to personal development.You want to be good parents or examples to your kids who honour hard work, intelligence, gratitude, kindness and manners.Learning to view life from other perspective.You want to teach your children to pick a good life partner who able to make them happy.

Very important. The largest hospital in my city is suffering financial losses from accepting patients who have developed fatal illnesses like cancer, which began to refuse those patients by saying that their illnesses are impossible to be cured. The fact is if you bribe the doctor, impossible is nothing. So, I’m preparing for my fund to bribe the doctor in the future. I’ve been treated in this hospital and have students whose grandpa used to be the head of the hospital, so I know what exactly is going on in my amazing “communist” country. My alternative is to choose hospitals in S.E Asian regions such as HK and Taiwan, but I need the money.I’m 33 and gonna end up my life being a loner, so I need a retirement fund, since my social security can only offer me a minimum of financial guarantee. Currently, my mom’s pension is about 2000 RMB. I can live a minimal life, but I don’t know what would happen in the future.Chinese tend to judge a book by its cover, so I have to at least keep the cover “normal”, if not luxurious. I can tolerate my fellow country men’s rolling eyes, but I have to get my business going when I go to see the principals or the CEO.One Taiwanese ask me to change my motto to: become a rich senior citizen. I know what he means and I agree with this brutal fact. The pursuit of spritual satisfaction sometimes has to be stopped for a foreseeable future, just once for a while.

This is far too open of a question…. Money is vital to an economy. We can’t pay for things without it, businesses can’t exist, people can’t earn… Did you mean that??? Or did you mean to focus on “How linked to money is your own personal happiness?” - that’s a better question… At a personal level, having ample money gives security. Having enough money in the bank to pay bills, to save a bit for retirement, to have an emergency funds, to bank for kids college… all provides security. Being debt free and living in a paid for house, and paying cash for a new car… all VERY FREEING… Now, once all your life needs are taken care of and you have enough money to walk out of your job on your own schedule, and never work again - how important is amassing even more money? That’s different for everyone. Are you wanting to underwrite a foundation to address world problems, like clean water in 3rd world countries? Then build away! If you’re goal is to live a simple life and not be a burden to your family, then that’s great too! Just make sure that all the “living for today” doesn’t cause your siblings to have to divert thousands (ten’s of thousands) of dollars to you and your spouse in your final years because you failed to plan, which I’ve seen with my carefree Aunt and Uncle. I’ve got a carefree sister who’s already been put on notice that her family is NOT going to fund her lifestyle, and she’s now out of money and options. Money is that important to me. I’m taking care of me and my wife and not the wayward sister who’s made 30 years of her own choices that are now having ramifications.

To me money is only a tool. It is like the hammer for the carpenter or the kitchenknife for the cook. If the carpenter use his hammer in the wrong way, he will not succeed. But if bove craftmen uses there tools as craftmen should do, they can create buteful things that enjoy people who needs those things. The same with money. Use it in the wrong way and you will not enjoy it completely. And be a scroog and you will not enjoy it totally. On top of that, it is an art to find a balance between enjoying live right now and preparing the future. This is as far as my direct answer to your question goes. Here under I give you my system of handling money. But you do not need to read it, if you do not want to. ———————————————- ———————————————- The answers have been written for other topics. You have to “translate” it to your question. Not everything is meant for your question. Do yourself a favor, read until the end. “How do I start?” 1. Take care of your physical and psychological health in the first place!! This remark has nothing to do with your question, but is inspired by the fact that health is more important than money. 2. First things first. When your money arrives in your account, you FIRST save money (10%), SECOND reduce debt (10%) and THIRD spend money. Otherwise you will find out that there will be almost never money left to save. Then “forget” (as a matter of speaking) that you have saved. 3. What one have to learn about money is that it is just a tool that need to be used in the proper way. A key is a tool to open the lock that keeps the door shut. Throw it through the window and you will not be able to open the right door, take the right care for it and you will be able to. Money is like the crop of a farmer. 10% of the crop is the basis of the crop of the next year. The rest is to make a living off. The farmer lives for his crop, because his crop gives life to so many people, not for the crop itself, but for what it does to himself and many people. The same with money. A scrooge goes for the money for no other reason than the money. A hard working person goes for the money, because it means a living. 4. Another piece of advice I always give is to buy 1 ounce of PHYSICAL silver each month and keep it until the day you retire. In the long run you will have profits. You will not easily sell the silver for other purposes (very important), so you will have your own retirement capital, even if it is a relatively small sum of money. If you are 20 years of age, you have lived for 240 months and you should have 240 ounces of physical silver. One ounce of silver costs now more or less $20, so you should not feel the buy in your budget, even if you have to buy two ounces for the next 240 months, because you started too late with that idea. 5. Choose also one note or coin, that you never spend when it comes into your hands by accident and in an honest way. “My coins” are pieces of €1 and €2. Put them in a jar and “forget” them for a long period of time. 6. Debt and alcohol works in the same way. Use both with moderation and you have pleasure. Enjoy too much and you have problems. Get addicted and you are in real trouble.. 7. Cut up your credit card and use a debit card instead. As far as I can know it is not that simple in the USA because of the laws about improper charges and fraud. 8. Avoid advertising. What ever they told you, the only purpose of advertising is to seduce you to spend your money on their stuff that you nine out of ten do not need anyway. I have a television that can stop and delay the broadcast. I stop at the beginning of the advertising and 7 minutes later I wind fast forward. Window shopping is also a form of advertising 9. 80% of all problems are caused by 20% of reasons. So if you can find out those 20% reasons that make you spend 80% of all your money, it makes easier for you to reduce your expenses. 10. Avoid bars, restaurants and paid entertainment. 11. A penny saved is a penny earned. Many, if not most spending vs. saving decisions occur in the small moments of life, at the pennies level. 12. Create a mantra in the sense of: “Financial succesful people save 10% of there income, are debt poor and enjoy live with the rest of there income.” Say this a thousend times to yourself every day and after many months your unconscious will believe this mantra and start help you to make come true that mantra. Do say “Succesful people do …”, not “I have to do …” because the latter give to much resistance of your unconscious. ——————————————- If you think only in terms of saving money, this could happen to your money. In the 1970’s there was a soap that was called “the six million dollar man”. It was a astronaut that had a terrible accident, but with the help of advanced technology and loads of money, he was rebuild and changed in a superstrong man that worked for the government. What I want to say is that six million dollar was in those days an astronomic high number, a bit like six billion is today. Now it is “just” a big number. Inflation can “eat” away your purchasing power. ——————————————— My way of paying of debt is the 1%-method. I advise you to use 10% of your income for debt repayment. However one want to feel a result almost directly after pay off a sum of money. This is the way one can do it. month 1: $1000 debt. Pay off 1% or $10. month 2 : $990 debt. Pay off 1% or $9.90. month 3: $980.10 debt. Pay off 1% or 9.80 month 4: $970.3 debt. Pay off 1% or 9.7 and your new debt amount is $960.6 Now you will “feel” your effort of paying off debt two ways. You pay back every month a little less and you pay less interest every month. You can play with that 1%-roule. You can make it 5% every month or 0.5%. I gave you an example of what is possible. But make sure that every month the debt is smaller than the month before with at least the percentage you have chosen. ———————————————- “How to invest?” There are two ways. Rental real estate and a combination from precious metals and stocks.Real Estate: Buy a small house or a garage with morgage. Rent it to someone (a garage ask less maintenance) Pay off the morgage with the rent and sell it. ———————————————— When playing the game Monopoly there is almost always a player who chooses to stay on his money in the beginning. At first it seems like a nice strategy. Every time when 'Start' is passed, this player sees his capital grow. This strategy goes well until others start buying houses and hotels. All of a sudden, rent must be paid everywhere. For the player who stayed on his money, the inevitable bankruptcy does not follow much later. In real life it is not entirely true that a person ultimately owns everything, and all others do nothing at all. But in real life too it is true that those who invest their money in assets that raise money themselves (shares for example) are ultimately far better off than those who stay on their money and do not invest. How do you win? How do you win with Monopoly? Buy as many properties as possible. And preferably the orange and red streets because they have the highest expected return. Well considered are the value shares of the Monopoly game! And nice to know: the very most expensive streets - Kalverstraat and Leidschestraat - do not turn out to be such attractive streets to buy. Compare them with the most beloved shares of the moment, the expected return is actually not good at all. The game Monopoly can not be compared completely to real life, of course. But in real life there is certainly a strategy to become rich: 1) Always live below your means, so that there is money to invest; 2) Invest the saved money in assets that raise money yourself. As with Monopoly, it is virtually impossible in real life to save yourself richly. In contrary, it is virtually impossible not to become rich when, for a few decades, both items are held above. Money is not everything, but money is something very important. Beyond the basic needs, money helps us achieve our life's goals and supports — the things we care about most deeply — family, education, health care, charity, adventure and fun. It helps us get some of life's intangibles — freedom or independence, the opportunity to make the most of our skills and talents, the ability to choose our own course in life, financial security. With money, much good can be done and much unnecessary suffering can be avoided or eliminated. But, money has its own limitations too. It can give us the time to appreciate the simple things in life more fully, but not the spirit of innocence and wonder necessary to do so. Money can give us the time to develop our gifts and talents, but not the courage and discipline to do so. Money can give us the power to make a difference in the lives of others, but not the desire to do so. It can give us the time to develop and nurture our relationships, but not the love and caring necessary to do so. It can just as easily make us jaded, escapist, selfish, and lonely. How much do you need? What is it going to cost you to get it? It is keeping these two questions in mind that gives us a true sense of money's relationship to happiness. If we have less than what we need, or if what we have is costing us too much, we can never be happy. We need money to eat, sleep, dress, work, play, relate, heal, move about, and enjoy comforts. We should remember in choosing our style that it comes with a price tag. The importance of money in human life is similar to the importance of food for the body. Just like you can't live even for a few days without food, you can't survive for long without Money. Whoever thinks money can't buy happiness, please transfer to my account :) Anyone who says Money can't buy happiness just doesn't know where to shop. Thanks for reading.

Let’s face it and be completely honest. In our material world, money is a huge factor. At all levels of society, it makes a difference. For the very poor, having some money is essential for survival. For the middle income earners, how much of it we can get a hold of and as importantly, how it is allocated/used, determines the quality of your current living and your eventual retirement. For the wealthy, it is a constant effort to keep it and not abuse it. The huge problem is when there is greed or when people subscribe to the common misconception that money makes you happy and/or it takes all your cares away. I heard somewhere someone saying “Mourning a loss within the comforts of a Benz, is far more appealing than having to shed tears inside a standard motor vehicle.” This may be the case, but chasing money and possessions is a quick fix and a addictive habit. Yes, being comfortable financially is important and does make life easier. But not in isolation. You also need to look after your health, including your emotional health. You need relationships, people in your life, who care about you and who you care about. Attending a recent funeral, for a wealthy deceased man: The speaker had prepared a detailed eulogy with inserts from many of the attendees. Not once in the speech was there any mention of money or wealth. The only points of interest was the relationships and the personality and the emotional contributions that the deceased had shared with his family, friends, colleagues, acquaintances and society in general.

While all the previous answers are correct about money being a store of value and making trade easier, I think one very important point remains unspoken: Money is how society deals with the allocation of scarce resources. That's why breathing air is free, for example - there's lots of air. But diamonds are expensive, because there is a lot of demand for them and very little supply. How do we fairly allocate those diamonds? Make them available for the people who are willing to pay the most for them. By using money (and capitalism) society can try to find ways to provide more of what people desire and less of what people don't want, thus attempting to maximize everyone's satisfaction. Every time money is exchanged (willfully) both parties are better off. If I spend $5 on a cheeseburger, I'd rather have the cheeseburger than $5. And the company that provided the cheeseburger is selling them for $5 because it benefits them to do so. If all of a sudden demand for cheeseburgers skyrockets and the price rises to $8, society will try to fulfill the demand by producing more cheeseburgers until the price reaches a point where it no longer makes sense to produce more cheeseburgers (no company is making an extreme profit) and thus consumer surplus is also increased. Likewise if demand for cheeseburgers drops, society will put efforts into producing other more beneficial things instead.
