If you want an answer as simple as the question: Money is like sex; it's not important unless you don't have any. A more realistic answer is: Trade is a tool which is most notably used to facilitate cooperation among strangers, allowing people to acquire otherwise unavailable resources. Currency is a different tool used to facilitate trade among groups of people with different needs, particularly with different resource availability times. Example: Person A needs flower to bake bread, but has no access to grain. They do, however, have hens that lay eggs. Person B needs eggs to go with their cheese, but do not have access to hens. They do, however, have access to dairy cows that are used to produce cheese. Person C needs cheese to go with their bread, but has no access to dairy cows. They do, however, have access to grain. All three of these people have what another needs, but may not all be able to physically meet up at the same time and make to logical swap. Currency is a way for all three to acquire what they individually need, on their own time, without having to coordinate a meeting among all three of them. Its fundamental usefulness is to enhance personal agency and make trade more efficient. It has been of great importance since its inception and will continue to be for a long time to come. That's not to say that it will forever be the way we operate as a species, but realistically, it is currently the way we operate, and will continue to be for the foreseeable future. In short, money is important. I wish it wasn't, but it definitely is. What's more important is happiness, don't forget that, and good luck trying to balance the two with the rest of life.

The Role of Money in Life  When it comes to our finances, each of us has our own individual approach. Some of us are savers, some are spenders, and others are somewhere in between. This continuum is a paradigm that our popular culture uses to frame differences in the way people approach money. I believe that the way we approach our finances goes beyond that particular behavioral characteristic. In reality, I think our approach to finances can be viewed in more of a multi-dimensional setting, where money has a different role in each our lives. For some, money means survival, plain and simple. For others, money is something that is a part of their lives but rarely on their mind, regardless of the role it actually plays. For yet others, money is an obsession, as accumulation signifies achievement. Some people view money as analogous to insurance, or a defensive resource to protect against future setbacks. Some people want money to provide a good home….or to contribute to the ability to have certain hobbies….or to provide something to bequeath to future generations….and so on. Sometimes the same person may view money differently in different situations. The bottom line is that we each have our own relationship with money, and our own conscious and subconscious needs for money, rooted in our value systems and cumulative life experiences. This is an area of personal finance that has interested me for a while. Why do people behave the way they do with respect to their money? What’s driving this behavior? Of course, a starting point for anybody is to consider how you personally view things. Taking an introspective approach, I have spent time figuring out my own take on money, and the role it plays in my life. What I have determined is that for me, it fits into a framework that includes the following elements: Health, Wealth, and Relationships. These are linked together as a part of a system. Think about it: HWR – Health, Wealth, Relationships. They’re all connected, and to the extent one is strengthened, the others will be strengthened as well. If one is weakened, the others will be weakened as well. For example, lets take 2 people: A and B. They are twins. A has good health, average wealth, and good relationships. B has good health, average wealth, and poor relationships. Over time, all other things being equal, I think that A will end up having a better overall quality of life. My reasoning is that A’s good relationships will be good for his happiness and will lower his stress levels compared to B, which will give A a chance to be healthier. As A is healthier, he will have a better chance to be wealthier, as he will be able to in better position to earn money while having lower health care expenses. And while he is healthier, he in turn will be in a better position to cultivate, keep, and grow relationships, leading to better chances to be wealthy, etc. Circular, perhaps…yet very symbiotic. So to me, money is a part of the Wealth aspect of HWR. Beyond basic survival, money gives you the opportunity to live a healthier life, with the time and means to have more positive relationships. One thing I want to make clear is that I am not saying that money buys friends. Well, it could, but those aren’t true friends. What I am saying is that the more money you have, on balance, the less stressed you are about it, and the more time you have to do other things, such as cultivate true, genuine relationships that aren’t based on money. Money is but a component in the system. Of course, there is no right or wrong framework, each of us has our own specific one, whether we have consciously thought about it or not. Yours might be entirely different than mine. It would be interesting to get everyone’s perspectives on the role of money in our lives, in relation to other aspects. What do you think?

It is not important. It's the opposite, money is even detrimental to life in general. Money is the mean to accumulate wealth which cause economic inequality. In nature, no creature except human use money or a concept of it and they never ask something in return when giving something. A nut tree will not ask something in return from a bird who eat its nuts. But actually the tree will get something in return in a big cycle but not immediately. This is how the concept of "pay it forward" originated. I think money is born from the individualistic and greedy nature of human. Once implemented, it changes the way people think. With money in the system, everytime someone gives something to someone else, she/he could think that someone is owing him/her something which can be paid back with money. Then the whole trading system is born. People start quantifying the value of everything, and people become less and less giving.

Before the invention of money, there was barter. I will trade you 1 sheep for 5 hens. I will work 8 hours in your field for 2 dozen eggs from your hens. One thing to note is that barter exchanges commonly are ad hoc, with no well-defined exchange ratios worked out beforehand. Also, what if I have nothing that you need? Maybe you don’t need my sheep. How else will I get some hens? Money is an agreed-upon medium of exchange that facilitates transactions between individuals, between institutions, and between individuals and institutions. Having a reasonably well-known price for hens, with the price expressed in some monetary unit, makes it a lot easier for me to find someone who will sell me some hens!

I got a call from my friend and her mom was hospitalised and was in ICU. Pulmonary Embolism- the condition where in clot shoots up to block the arteries in the lungs. No one could ever imagine a bone fracture in the leg could turn into a life threatening problem. Conditions got worse as the days passed. Her multiple organs stopped working. It was 4th day in ICU. There was neither any improvement nor any response from her mother except that she was still breathing on ventilator. Each day’s ICU charge was costing more than all the family members month's income put together. Scared of the bills that was shooting day by day, they decided to talk to the doctor. Doctor clarified she status of the case and gave them 2 options- Option 1- To keep her in ICU untill she gets back to consciousness. Her life organs would be supported with various machines. Doctor gave an example of similar case where one of the patient was back to consciousness after 21 days. Doctor also admitted on the bad chances where she could never get alright. In this case the family should be ready to shell out Lakhs of money with 50% chances of her survival. Option 2– The hospital will help the easy passing of the person by removing the ventilators and machine support. She could survive atmost few hours after the support is removed. My friend was broken. All of the family members knew they could not go for the option 1. They were all forced to decide on practical terms and took a tough decision to go with the option 2. Hospital staff got all the formalities done from the family members to proceed with Option 2 and were all sent back to home that night and were informed that they would get a call from hospital if there is any news about her. Later, next day she passed away. True is that philosophy that states Money is not important and can't buy many things like love, life, peace etc. But it has the power to postpone death, could even save life in some cases. Respect money! “Live and let live"

And then some of them left (draining everything through their right ear). I don't blame them, that's why they are common people, they can't understand and follow such tough preachings. Soon a few new devotees entered the scene. They looked rich and influential. Saint called them in front and made them sit near him. Others had to shift at back. Next, a healthy discussion about building a brand new temple started. The big, beautiful “Dhaam” (temple) dedicated to the same saint who was giving a lesson of simplicity a few moments back. They discussed about the entire layout, arranging of funds, type of stone to be used, attractions, getting in more investment etc. Saint’s face lit up while having all these discussions, the happiness on his face was amazing. God bless those investors, sorry followers. Soon, I left the place after pledging not to return.  Answering this question- No, money is not important, if it is of relevance to others ;)

Recently, I went to a shop for snacks. I saw an old aged man who lives in my locality. He didn't notice me. He took a packet of bread and butter. He gave coins to the shopkeeper. “Agali baar chillar leke mat aana,” shopkeeper shouted at him. “Don't bring coins next time,” shopkeeper shouted at him. He didn't say anything. He took his stuffs and turned to leave but turned back suddenly, “Please, give me a recharge coupon of Rs.10,” he said with stumbled calmly voice. “lijiye,” shopkeeper gave it. “Paise baad me de denge,” he replied. O my God! Shopkeeper snatched that card from his hand. “Paise le kr aana fir lena, roj-roj ka ho gya hai,” angrily shopkeeper told him. “Take it,” shopkeeper gave it. “ I'll pay you next time,” he replied. “Bring money then take it, it's a habit,” angrily shopkeeper told him. I was stunned by the scene. The old man belongs to a good family and there is no issues regarding money. When he left, I inquired shopkeeper behind his rude behaviour. “His son says not to give a single thing, simply refute when he comes. Everytime I can't help him. I don't want to get fired,” shopkeeper revealed. It shocked me brutally. I told my mom about this incident. She said that he is a retired professor. He didn't save money for his future, gave all facilities to his son. Now, his son treats him like a burden. I skuled my sorrow. Hopelessly I left. Why? The person who sacrificed his happiness for his son is facing cruel world? Yes, money is important. Not only important, it can make your life. It can give respect in this rude society. Thanks for reading.

response.answer_text: Money is too important my friend. I am the guy who really did what millions say …the Money isn't important. So i quit a Fortune 500 Petroleum Exploration behemoth…yes i did. And i was 32 then. I joined after that in much lower paying jobs. It took me 10 years to come back to the level of pay i had quit in 2008. I lost friends. I lost my logic. People just left me including extended family members like cousins. Even now whenever my past is discussed either amongst friends, current colleagues or in interviews, the most perplexing question put before me is …Why did you quit that job..it paid so well. I know in my heart that i quit because my heart had then screamed out ….your self respect is more important than money. Yes…i had quit listning to that scream. But the world doesn't run on emotions, however true they may be. The world runs on hard facts and money is a piece of fact that just….is.

Money isn’t the most important thing in life(at least not to me). People are so bent on making money that they think it is the entire reason to get an education in the first place. So they hastily just pick a major they think they are interested in. Then they struggle to learn everything they are taught in the courses (many drop-out). If they make it, they still have to hunt for a place to work. Then they get caught in a career where they make money, but they don’t have any fun. And fun is important, because they will spend the rest of their lives in this career: and if they aren’t having any fun, it will be dreadful to them, and they might develop a variety of emotional, physical, and mental health problems.  We live in a society where everything is measured by money. Even our well-being is suppose to correlate to our bank account. Students are getting jobs in advertising, marketing, all areas that help fuel this massive consumerism, and why do they go to these areas? Do not major in something superficial or that leads to a corporate trap. Major in something rich in knowledge. Something you truly enjoy. Happiness, go for it. Money is soulless. Don’t sell your soul so it can have its power over you. Find a thing that you always dreamed about and do it.

Not very - I was introduced to many valuable ideas through Robert Kiyosaki’s book, Rich Dad, Poor Dad. One particularly useful lesson is that - assuming you at least make enough to get you by - you should work to learn, not to make money. People learn best when they have a curious mind and are genuinely interested in the things they do. Those who learn better and feel happier are more socially engaged, enjoy more career success, and - yes - tend to make more money. Likewise, many Americans seem to have the dilemma of spending beyond their means or not paying themself first (these ideas are also discussed in Rich Dad, Poor Dad). You shouldn’t work for money, money should work for you. Money used to buy things that add no value to your life or the lives of people you love is money wasted. Trim the fat before you ask for more, and learn to manage your money before you demand “your fair share”.

It helps in trade. If money is not used the other means is barter: You give me X item and I swap it for Y. The trouble with barter is how do you define the variation in values between items X and Y? E.g. is a bag of apples more valuable than a bottle of milk, about the same, less valuable, by how much? If different then how do you accomplish a fair trade through barter? Say you have a watermelon but you want a glass of milk. Do you trade the entire watermelon? Do you cut off a piece and compromise the rest? Do you ask for many glasses instead?  What if you don't particularly want the milk (just now). But later you might. Do you trade now and store the milk somewhere? Or do you wait until you need the milk and only then trade the watermellon (which might have gone off by then)? What if you don't want the milk but you know someone else who does, and he's got some grapes which you want. Do you trade the watermellon for the milk and then trade the milk for the grapes? What if you didn't know the 3rd person wanted milk? So the 4 major reasons money is easier to use than barter: A means to measure value of different products.An easy way to divide up value among various products.A non-perishable store of value.A non-specific transfer of value.Money as we have it today isn't perfect on those elements. E.g. inflation causes its storage capability to be less constant. But its benefits still outweigh the problems.

You can actually do without a great many things or you can “make do” with things in good but used condition. You don’t have to spent all your time in pursuit of money. The people around you, friends, family and even pets, should be your top priority, but…..I can’t really define your priorities, only you can do that. Only YOU can decide what’s most important to do with your time and whatever money you earn. Doing things that nourish your soul is what will make you happiest in the long run. I’ve never heard of an epitaph that said “I should have worked longer or harder”

This story is not about me.. it's about my father and his parents and his siblings My father grew up in a small village of Bharatpur (India) along with his other 7 siblings as the philosophy during my grandparents time per “jitne hath…utna paisa” (more hands,more money). My grandparents were not from any rich background.. they used to work in someone else's field to fullfill their own family's stomach. Back in days, method of payment were not in money form, Jamindar (Field lord) used to give the daily wedges in the form of Grains..which was further stored in vaults made of clay by my grandma…my father along with his siblings used to stole a tiny-tiny amount of grain with the help of broom sticks in the exchange of candies from the cyclist which used to visit our separate part of tiny village,weekly..but as i mentioned there were 8 of them and vaults were made of clay…every winters, grains were always in shortage. My grandmother told me that how many times she slept hungry…but always provided everyone for at least one meal. My grandparents used to work during night in fields to provide a ‘bit extra' which actually meant food atleast twice a day for them, during winters when the moon shines the brightest…it was only time when the electricity was consistent and pumps will provide enough water to irritate the field in one go…as we never owned any land of our own back than…to irrigate mustard field for extra income was a good idea but it was not a consistent..but something is better than sleeping empty stomach..right?. Years went by and working in those chilly night with water till you knees ( Indian farmers are not very advance…we use a system “kood modna” in which a person manually put sand to stop the flow of water in one particular direction) and drinking only Chach (buttermilk…because milk was only for special occasions ) really took a toll on her. She developed a continuous pain in her knees. My father and my uncle were living far away from home those days so they were not aware of any of those conditions. My grandpa took my her to the nearest Doctor..he declared that it is just normal pain due to age (she was around 40) and gave her some medicines which was actually cheap and affordable as compare to other medicines and was much more effective than than those 'expensive medicine'. Years passed by..my father completed his Degree in maths- science and applied for Competitive exams for State Engineering service. Result came out but he passed the technical but failed in English. My grandparent were raising and trying to pay the fee for other 3 brothers too and also, 4 of his sisters were coming to the age of marrying so it was a great burden for them to collect enough for their marriage and for Dowry. My grandpa refused to gave him money and advised him to apply for Nursing Course which was a much cheaper option. My father followed the advice as he knew that as fast as he gets the job.. faster his family will recover from poverty and second (my own opinion) it was not in anyone else's power to pay the fee form Exam forms again and drop the whole year. After year or two..my grandma's condition grew serious, but that time my father had enough knowledge to know what was wrong. She had rheumatic arthritis which mainly developed due to lack of nutrition and food basically and those 'cheap but effective' medicines were actually heavy doses of steroids which she were taking for all those years. By that time it was far too late for her to recover from the side effect. My father had a govt job as a male nurse by that time. He tried his best… tprovidedher the best medicine and best treatment.. but it was late. She died a cruel death…i don't even want to recall her condition during her last years for this question but I'm glad she died! She suffered for 18 years in her body. Followed years, all my uncle and aunty got married..got govt Jobs. My grandpa now owns a fair amount of land which he can't even irrigate by himself. Now I'm not going to answer thst if money is important? Cz even I'm not sure what thing took away my grandma's life..or another opportunity for my father to get a good job, what thing took away his childhood…and if money is really that powerful and impo can it bring back all the things they all lost? Was it Time,which messed up things up for them..or was it the money..or was it simply the Indian philosophy of having 8 children when you already knew you are broke af? The thing is..it doesn't matter atleast not now for me.

Yet every month we seem to make rent and get most of our bills paid, but there are a lot of other things that need attention that aren’t getting fixed. So I keep praying and going to Mass in the hope He will respond. Patience, patience, patience … !

The problem is with those who choose to live in Love-focused ways, Especially after they figure out that they are spiritual beings having human experiences, you cannot control them. This scares the bejeebers out of those who only know how to control those who will stay in Fear. Start your journey to becoming Love anyway. There is an explosion in the number of humans choosing to go that way and you will have lots of company - you will not ‘see’ them until you start leaving Fear behind, then you will be amazed at how many Love-focused people there are all around you. Yeah, to a point, and from a certain perspective which is valid for most living humans. If you’re seriously hungry, thirsty, or in need of shelter or other basics, then money is everything, in a system where you need money to get anything. If you’re desperately poor, then yes, money is more important that most anything else, because your survival depends on acquiring it somehow. After you have enough of the basics for life, money becomes less and less important, to the point that very wealthy people have the luxury of declaring that money doesn’t matter at all. The truth is that you need a minimum of about $75k per year to live in the US, much more in many hip, techy, coastal places. If you’re below that threshold, you are probably doing everything you can to rise above it. If you’re above it, you’re probably doing everything you can to bring meaning, purpose, and real satisfaction to your life, because you don’t lack for the basics. Money is power. Property is theft. Cheers.

Money is how the world tells you what you are worth based on how useful they find your particular set of skills. Make a wrong career choice, and you will struggle; choose a career in demand, and you have less financial problems than you would otherwise. The problem is we are asked to make an objective decision at a point in our life when we are idealistic; so many people choose with the purity of their heart and the nobility of their dreams. Later, the harsh reality of life, which can be more cruel in more ways than you can imagine, will cut like a sword, and the only thing that matters is whether you make / have money to survive and prosper, or you don’t. Everything else is bulls*it. To reach a state of abundance while pursuing what you like is rare, and you have to be either extremely lucky, or fine tune your life over a long time to get it there. When you are still in school, you can do anything (infinite potential). As you approach graduation, you have to renounce most of those possibilities and pick one you have a high likelihood of being good at (if you really work it). Of course, you can also choose to keep yourself open to that connection to infinite choices by never picking anything to devote your full attention to, but the bills at the end of each month make for a very rude awakening; and any person who can’t take care of him/herself will not be prized or valued much in a society where you have to prove your skill at taking care of yourself and of those who depend on you.

Historically, early societies did not have money. In situations where there was no surplus and the sole goal of a civilization was survival, money was not needed. As societies developed simple tools and domesticated animals, there was some surplus and people may have bartered. Bartering exists even today, though I have no idea how many societies exist with no exchange of money. There may exist some isolated groups who may not use money. I think that money is a necessary construct in industrial and post-industrial societies today. I cannot imagine many developed societies who have no need for a monetary system.

If you live in a country where the quality of medical care will depend on your financial resources, not having money can literally be fatal. Taxes are likely to be lower than they should be to support society in the long term. You will not have access to educational resources, or it will be limited, and infrastructure will likely be decaying. It comes down to a question of values. First, I reject the premise of the question that money is more valuable than anything — it’s not. There are many, many things that are much more valuable that any amount of money: happiness, love, fulfillment, peace, etc, etc. Now let’s move on to material goods and services: To say that money is more valuable than any other thing is rather silly. If that were true, then all commerce would come to a screeching halt as we would never give up any money to buy any other items or services. Now, let’s look at what money IS and what it represents: money is a storage and transfer mechanism for value or wealth. It represents, in the most financially liquid form, ALL OTHER goods and services. Therefore, FAR from being the “root of all evil”, money is a great thing in that it lubricates and facilitates commerce, which leads to prosperity — increased economic welfare. We would do well to remember that the tired old saw, “Money is the root of all evil” is actually a misquote from the Bible. The actual quote is, “For the LOVE of money is the root of all evil.” There’s a huge difference between these two statements. The first assigns agency to money, which has none, and lifts some portion of blame from the individual who may be guilty of materialism. The latter (correct) quote correctly teaches that a love of material things is the root of all evil, since money is merely the liquid form of all material things.

We got away from the practice for barter trade, Even today we may find some instances of exchanging the goods as a trade. It is no more recognized way of doing any transaction. No single person process every necessity nor the time, it is inevitable for a social mechanism to exchange what is in excess with what is scares. Earlier when the money was notional the person who had big stock of cattle or pile of grains was a rich. He would exchange them to fulfill his wants. In modern economy the currency has replaced the exchange value of Utility, we can not get away from the wants, when we have wants, those need to be fulfilled, to full fill them we need to give back some thing in exchange. That exchangeable matter is called Money. Hence until we have wants, money is going to be eternal in one or other forms

CREDIT CARDS CREDIT INSURANCE SAVINGS RETIREMENT MORTGAGES STUDENT LOANS TAXES FINANCIAL PLANNING REVIEWS HOME YOUR MONEY CONTRIBUTORS Interviewing over 1,200 rich people has taught me exactly how money affects the most important things in our lives Steve Siebold, Contributor Aug 31, 2015, 8:15 PM  Money makes the best things in life better. Tom Shaw / Getty Images Money has a bad reputation with people who don't have it. It has been blamed for everything from wars to infidelity, from destroying friendships to wrecking families. In the minds of the masses, the more ways they can demonize money, the more validated they feel for not seeking their own fortunes. Instead of seeing the positive ways that money can enhance the most important things in life like our health, family relationships, and friendships, most people would rather scorn money and tell you how it can destroy the things we hold closest to our hearts. Don't listen to negative people who don't know any better. The truth is money is not the most important thing in life, but it will make the most important things in life so much better.

The main attribute that money bestows, provided you have enough of it, is freedom. Being independently wealthy, not beholden to a daily job or other constraint, allows you the time and resources to accomplish whatever you desire. If you want to climb Mount Everest, you hire some experienced climbers and guides and you do it. Want to record an album? Rent some studio time, hire some songwriters and session players and record away. Do you want to immerse yourself in research at the most prestigious universities? Go there, make a sizable donation, and research away. Money frees you from the need to be anywhere in particular at any given time. You set your own schedule and follow it or break it as you wish.

15 years ago, I wanted to be a priest. I didn't want to join the rat race, so I chose to work in a non-profit company until the time I could join the seminary. One day my dad later asked me, “Son, how's it going? Still don't want to join the rat race?” “Great, dad!” I said. “It's going great! I see all my friends struggling in the rat race. I'm glad I'm not in it.” “Son,” he said, “so long as you use money, you're in the rat race. Don't kid yourself that you're not.” And he was right! I may not have thought I was in the rat race, but I was. Later, when I decided not to pursue religious life anymore, I realised that at the age of 27, I knew almost nothing about money and how it works. I realised that I was stuck working in a non-profit and my pay was never going to be very high. I had to learn how money works and how to make it work harder for me. Three years later, I fell seriously ill and could not work for a year. Having money in the bank tied me over and paid for my wedding. When I went back to work, it was in a job where I taught people about money and how to make it work for them. I'm still doing it. Money is an enabler, a lubricant and fuel for life. It's not the most important thing, but it affects everything else that's important to me.

Given that individually we are neither all-skilled nor self-sufficient, it is desired to trade with our fellow man to acquire the goods and services we need.  Barter is extremely inefficient, since it relies on the "double coincidence" of finding a single person who needs what you have and who also has something you want.  Money thus becomes a useful intermediary store of value to facilitate trade.

Money allows us to interact relatively smoothly with strangers.  You get money from your work or from selling goods and services.  You use money to buy goods and services produced mostly by people you have never met. This does not apply just to private commerce.  You also pay various taxes and get various services from the state.  Entire economies can run this way: both the Soviet Union and China were doing OK and growing quite fast before a new generation of leaders decided to change this.  (This gets denied by the dominant New Right ideology, but you can find the hard facts at The World Economy: Historical Statistics by Angus Maddison. He was not at all pro-Communist or pro-Chinese, but his project was to give accurate estimates of growth wherever these could be found.) It comes down to combinatorics.   If there a n categories of goods and services trading among them selves   you would have the number of barters  o(n^2).   Whereas if you use money the complexity becomes o(n). For large n this is the difference between practical and practically impossible.  Money (i.e. some universally accepted trade item) is necessary for efficient commerce.
